revision.comment: Replacing BrianBinnie.jpg with [[File:Brian_Binnie_by_Don_Ramey_Logan.jpg]] (by [[commons:User:CommonsDelinker|CommonsDelinker]] because: [[:c:COM:FR|File renamed]]: [[:c:COM:FR#FR1|Criterion 1]] (original uploader’s request)).
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox astronaut | name = William Brian Binnie | image = Brian Binnie by Don Ramey Logan.jpg | type = [[Commercial astronaut]]
[[File:US - FAA Astronaut Wings.png|150px]] | nationality = American | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1953}} | death_date = | birth_place = [[West Lafayette, Indiana]], U.S. | death_place = | occupation = [[Test pilot]] | rank = [[Commander]], [[United States Navy]] | selection = [[List of astronauts by year of selection#2003|SpaceShipOne 2003]] | space_time = ~5 minutes | missions = [[SpaceShipOne flight 17P]] | insignia = }} '''William Brian Binnie''' (born 1953) is a former United States Navy officer and is one of the test pilots for [[SpaceShipOne]], the experimental [[spaceplane]] developed by [[Scaled Composites]]. ==History== [[File:Wife of astronaut Brian Binnie greets him upon compleation of the final flight photo D Ramey Logan.jpg|thumb|left|Wife Bub Binnie upon completion of the final flight]] Binnie was born in [[West Lafayette, Indiana]], where his Scottish father William P. Binnie was a professor of physics at [[Purdue University]]. The family returned to Scotland when Binnie was five, and lived in [[Aberdeen]] (his father taught at [[University of Aberdeen|Aberdeen University]]) and later in [[Stirling]].{{cite news |url=http://icstirlingshire.icnetwork.co.uk/observer/news/tm_method=full%26objectid=17409899%26siteid=92391-name_page.html |title=Stirling has a space ace |work=Stirling Observer |date=July 19, 2006 |accessdate=November 4, 2006}} When Binnie was a teenager the family moved to [[Boston]].{{cite news |url=http://www.princeton.edu/~paw/archive_new/PAW04-05/09-0223/features4.html |title=Rocket man |work=Princeton Alumni Weekly |first=Kathy |last=Kiely |date=February 23, 2005 |accessdate=November 4, 2006}} Binnie, an alumnus of [[Brown University|Brown]] and [[Princeton University|Princeton]] Universities, served for 21 years in the [[United States Navy]] as a [[United States Naval Aviator|naval aviator]] flying the [[A-7 Corsair II]], [[A-6 Intruder]], [[F/A-18 Hornet]], and [[AV-8B Harrier II]]. He graduated from the [[United States Naval Test Pilot School|U.S. Naval Test Pilot School]] in 1988. Binnie also copiloted the Atmospheric Test Vehicle of the [[Rotary Rocket]]. In 2006, he received an Honorary degree from University of Aberdeen.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/go/pr/fr/-/1/hi/scotland/north_east/5140682.stm |title=Degree for 'first Scot in space' |work=BBC News |date=July 3, 2006 |accessdate=November 4, 2006}} ===SpaceShipOne and spaceflight=== On December 17, 2003, the 100th anniversary of the [[Wright brothers]]' first powered flight, Binnie piloted the first powered test flight of SpaceShipOne, [[SpaceShipOne flight 11P|flight 11P]], which reached a top speed of Mach 1.2 and a height of {{convert|20.7|km|mi|disp=flip}}. On October 4, 2004, he piloted SpaceShipOne's second [[Ansari X Prize]] flight, [[SpaceShipOne flight 17P|flight 17P]], winning the X Prize and becoming the 435th person to go into space. His flight, which peaked at {{convert|367442|ft|mi km|1}}, set a winged aircraft altitude record,"[http://www.fai.org/fai-record-file/?recordId=9881 FAI Record ID #9881 – Altitude above the earth's surface with or without maneuvres of the aerospacecraft, Class P-1 (Suborbital missions)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151018225245/http://www.fai.org/fai-record-file/?recordId=9881 |date=October 18, 2015 }}" [http://www.fai.org/fai-record-file/?recordId=10434 Mass] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924043352/http://www.fai.org/fai-record-file/?recordId=10434 |date=September 24, 2015 }} [http://www.fai.org/fai-record-file/?recordId=9882 Time] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924045447/http://www.fai.org/fai-record-file/?recordId=9882 |date=September 24, 2015 }} ''[[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale]] (FAI).'' Retrieved: 21 September 2014. breaking the old record set by the [[North American X-15]] in 1963.{{cite news |url=https://www.wired.com/science/space/news/2004/10/65212 |title=SpaceShipOne Wins the X Prize |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] | first=Dan |last=Brekke |date=October 4, 2004 |accessdate=November 4, 2006}} It also earned him the second set of [[Astronaut Badge|Astronaut Wings]] to be given by the [[Federal Aviation Administration|FAA]] for a flight aboard a privately operated commercial spacecraft.{{cite web |url=http://www.faa.gov/data_research/commercial_space_data/current_licenses/ |title=Active Commercial Space Licenses |work=FAA.gov |accessdate=May 3, 2009}} ===After space-shot=== In 2014 Binnie joined [[XCOR Aerospace]] as senior engineer and [[test pilot]], after working as a test pilot and program business manager for [[Scaled Composites]] for many years.{{cite news |url=http://www.spacenews.com/article/features/40089spaceship-pilot-joins-rival-firm |title=Spaceship Pilot Joins Rival Firm |work=Space News |first=Irene |last=Klotz |date=April 3, 2014 |accessdate=April 4, 2014}} ==Quotes== {{quote|I wake up every morning and thank God I live in a country where all of this is possible. Where you have the Yankee ingenuity to roll up your sleeves, get a band of people who believe in something and go for it and make it happen. It doesn't happen anywhere else.|Brian Binnie|October 4, 2004, after completing flight 17P}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Portal|Biography}} {{commons category|Brian Binnie}} * [http://www.scaled.com/projects/tierone/pilots/brian_binnie Biography at Scaled Composites website] * [http://www.spacefacts.de/bios/astronauts/english/binnie_brian.htm Biography at SpaceFacts.de] {{The Spaceship Company}} {{Scaled Composites}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Binnie, Brian}} [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American astronauts]] [[Category:Aviators from Indiana]] [[Category:Brown University alumni]] [[Category:Princeton University alumni]] [[Category:Commercial astronauts]] [[Category:Scaled Composites]] [[Category:Scaled Composites Tier One program]] [[Category:United States Navy officers]] [[Category:United States Naval Aviators]] [[Category:American test pilots]] [[Category:Flight altitude record holders]] [[Category:American people of Scottish descent]] [[Category:American aviation record holders]]
